pageProps.contentHtml:
Runge's theorem

Let U⊆CU \subseteq \CU⊆C be an open set and K⊆UK \subseteq UK⊆U be a compact subset of UUU.

  1. Prove that there exists a bounded open set VVV with K⊆V⊆V‾⊆UK \subseteq V \subseteq \cl{V} \subseteq UK⊆V⊆V⊆U such that ∂V\partial V∂V consists of finitely many closed ine segments.

    Hint: Consider a fine square grid.

  2. Let fff be a holomorphic function on UUU. Show that there exists a sequence {Rn}n\set{R_n}_n{Rn​}n​ of rational functions such that (i) Rn→fR_n \to fRn​→f uniformly on KKK and (ii) none of the functions RnR_nRn​ has a pole in KKK.

    Hint: First represent f(z)f\p{z}f(z) for z∈Kz \in Kz∈K as a suitable integral over the set ∂V\partial V∂V and then notice that the integrand is equicontinuous in zzz.
Solution.

  1. Let δ=12d(K,Uc)\delta = \frac{1}{2} d\p{K, U^\comp}δ=21​d(K,Uc). If δ=∞\delta = \inftyδ=∞, then use δ=1\delta = 1δ=1 instead. Consider the grid of rectangles

    R={[nδ,(n+1)δ]×[mδ,(m+1)δ] | n,m∈Z}\mathcal{R} = \set{\br{n\delta, \p{n+1}\delta} \times \br{m\delta, \p{m+1}\delta} \st n, m \in \Z}R={[nδ,(n+1)δ]×[mδ,(m+1)δ]∣n,m∈Z}

    which cover all of C\CC. Let

    V=(⋃R∈R∣R∩K≠∅R)o,V = \p{\bigcup_{R \in \mathcal{R} \mid R \cap K \neq \emptyset} R}^\itr,V=⎝⎛​R∈R∣R∩K=∅⋃​R⎠⎞​o,

    i.e., the interior of the union of these rectangles. This is a finite union, since KKK is compact.

    Notice that K⊆VK \subseteq VK⊆V: if z∈Kz \in Kz∈K, then certainly there is R∈RR \in \mathcal{R}R∈R such that z∈Rz \in Rz∈R. If z∈Roz \in R^\itrz∈Ro, then clearly z∈Vz \in Vz∈V. Otherwise, if z∈∂Rz \in \partial Rz∈∂R, then there are two cases: if zzz is not one of the vertices of RRR, then there is exactly one more rectangle R′R'R′ such that z∈∂R′z \in \partial R'z∈∂R′, and it's clear that z∈(R∪R′)oz \in \p{R \cup R'}^\itrz∈(R∪R′)o. In the other case, if zzz is a vertex of RRR, then zzz lies in exactly 444 rectangles from R\mathcal{R}R, and by the same argument, we still have z∈Vz \in Vz∈V.

    Finally, V‾⊆U\cl{V} \subseteq UV⊆U since δ\deltaδ was chosen to be small, and because V‾\cl{V}V is a finite union of rectangles, its boundary comprises of finitely many closed line segments.

  2. Let VVV be as in (1). We claim that

    f(z)=12πi∫∂Vf(ζ)ζ−z dζf\p{z} = \frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{\partial V} \frac{f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z} \,\diff\zetaf(z)=2πi1​∫∂V​ζ−zf(ζ)​dζ

    for any z∈Kz \in Kz∈K: since ∂V\partial V∂V consists of finitely many closed line segments, we can extend all of these segments into lines, which gives a grid on VVV. In this grid, if zzz lies in exactly one rectangle RRR, then by Cauchy's integral formula,

    12πi∫∂Vf(ζ)ζ−z dζ=12πi∫∂Rf(ζ)ζ−z dζ=f(z),\frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{\partial V} \frac{f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z} \,\diff\zeta = \frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{\partial R} \frac{f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z} \,\diff\zeta = f\p{z},2πi1​∫∂V​ζ−zf(ζ)​dζ=2πi1​∫∂R​ζ−zf(ζ)​dζ=f(z),

    since the integral will vanish on every other rectangle that doesn't contain zzz. If zzz lies on the boundary of a rectangle, then zzz is contained in the interior of a larger rectangle by the same argument as in (1), and the same representation holds.

    Let r=12d(K,∂V)r = \frac{1}{2} d\p{K, \partial V}r=21​d(K,∂V) which is positive since KKK and VcV^\compVc are closed. Then

    ∣f(ζ)ζ−z∣≤1rsup⁡ζ∈∂V∣f(ζ)∣<∞,\abs{\frac{f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z}} \leq \frac{1}{r} \sup_{\zeta \in \partial V} \abs{f\p{\zeta}} < \infty,∣∣​ζ−zf(ζ)​∣∣​≤r1​ζ∈∂Vsup​∣f(ζ)∣<∞,

    so {ζ↦f(ζ)ζ−z}z∈K\set{\zeta \mapsto \frac{f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z}}_{z \in K}{ζ↦ζ−zf(ζ)​}z∈K​ is equicontinuous. Let δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 be small enough so that if ∣ζ−w∣<δ\abs{\zeta - w} < \delta∣ζ−w∣<δ, then ∣f(ζ)ζ−z−f(ζ)w−z∣<ε\abs{\frac{f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z} - \frac{f\p{\zeta}}{w - z}} < \epsilon∣∣​ζ−zf(ζ)​−w−zf(ζ)​∣∣​<ε.

    Since ∂V\partial V∂V comprises of finitely many closed line segments, there exist γ1,…,γn\gamma_1, \ldots, \gamma_nγ1​,…,γn​ such that ∂V=γ1+⋯+γn\partial V = \gamma_1 + \cdots + \gamma_n∂V=γ1​+⋯+γn​. By uniform continuity of each of these, we may pick a partition 0=t0<t1<⋯<tN=10 = t_0 < t_1 < \cdots < t_N = 10=t0​<t1​<⋯<tN​=1 so fine so that ∣γj(tk+1)−γj(tk)∣<δ\abs{\gamma_j\p{t_{k+1}} - \gamma_j\p{t_k}} < \delta∣γj​(tk+1​)−γj​(tk​)∣<δ for each jjj. Approximating fff with Riemann sums, we get

    ∣f(z)−12πi∑j=1n∑k=0N−1f(ζk)ζk−z(γj(tk+1)−γj(tk))∣=∣12πi∫∂Vf(ζ)ζ−z dζ−12πi∑j=1n∑k=0N−1f(ζk)ζk−z(γj(tk+1)−γj(tk))∣=∣12πi∑j=1n∑k=0N−1∫tktk+1(f(γj(t))γj(t)−z−f(γj(tk))γj(tk)−z)γj′(t) dt∣≤12π∑j=1n∑k=0N−1∫tktk+1ε∣γj′(t)∣ dt=ε∑j=1n∣γj∣2π=ε∣∂V∣2π,\begin{aligned} \abs{f\p{z} - \frac{1}{2\pi i} \sum_{j=1}^n \sum_{k=0}^{N-1} \frac{f\p{\zeta_k}}{\zeta_k - z}\p{\gamma_j\p{t_{k+1}} - \gamma_j\p{t_k}}} &= \abs{\frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{\partial V} \frac{f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z} \,\diff\zeta - \frac{1}{2\pi i} \sum_{j=1}^n \sum_{k=0}^{N-1} \frac{f\p{\zeta_k}}{\zeta_k - z}\p{\gamma_j\p{t_{k+1}} - \gamma_j\p{t_k}}} \\ &= \abs{\frac{1}{2\pi i} \sum_{j=1}^n \sum_{k=0}^{N-1} \int_{t_k}^{t_{k+1}} \p{\frac{f\p{\gamma_j\p{t}}}{\gamma_j\p{t} - z} - \frac{f\p{\gamma_j\p{t_k}}}{\gamma_j\p{t_k} - z}}\gamma_j'\p{t} \,\diff{t}} \\ &\leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \sum_{j=1}^n \sum_{k=0}^{N-1} \int_{t_k}^{t_{k+1}} \epsilon \abs{\gamma_j'\p{t}} \,\diff{t} \\ &= \epsilon\sum_{j=1}^n \frac{\abs{\gamma_j}}{2\pi} \\ &= \epsilon \frac{\abs{\partial V}}{2\pi}, \end{aligned}∣∣​f(z)−2πi1​j=1∑n​k=0∑N−1​ζk​−zf(ζk​)​(γj​(tk+1​)−γj​(tk​))∣∣​​=∣∣​2πi1​∫∂V​ζ−zf(ζ)​dζ−2πi1​j=1∑n​k=0∑N−1​ζk​−zf(ζk​)​(γj​(tk+1​)−γj​(tk​))∣∣​=∣∣​2πi1​j=1∑n​k=0∑N−1​∫tk​tk+1​​(γj​(t)−zf(γj​(t))​−γj​(tk​)−zf(γj​(tk​))​)γj′​(t)dt∣∣​≤2π1​j=1∑n​k=0∑N−1​∫tk​tk+1​​ε∣∣​γj′​(t)∣∣​dt=εj=1∑n​2π∣γj​∣​=ε2π∣∂V∣​,​

    where ∣∂V∣\abs{\partial V}∣∂V∣ is the length of ∂V\partial V∂V, which depends only on KKK and is finite by construction. Hence, our bound is independent of ε\epsilonε, so fff can be uniformly approximated by linear combinations of rational functions of the form f(ζk)ζk−z\frac{f\p{\zeta_k}}{\zeta_k - z}ζk​−zf(ζk​)​, where ζk∈∂V∖K\zeta_k \in \partial V \setminus Kζk​∈∂V∖K, which was what we wanted to show.
